 IIRC the Americans refer to this as the China Syndrome. As I understand it your containment won't stand up to that.

The China syndrome was the common theory as to what would happen in the event of a melt down. Since 3-mile island it has been determined that the reaction would stop long before it could burn through the containment floor. Up until 3 mile island a test of the China syndrome theory was considered to be too dangerous and costly to attempt. The data gathered from the 3-mile island accident revealed that it would be physically impossible for the reaction to be sustained long enough to burn its way through the containment floor. There also was a design flaw found in the fuel rod assembly that was discovered, it was found that the tolerances were too tight and that under high temperatures would accelerate the reaction. It was found that by loosening up the tolerances the reaction in high temperatures would slow or stop with out any outside influence. The accident at 3-mile island actually was a good thing since it gave us invaluable information that other wise would have gone unknown.
 
 Actualy the reason that Chernobyl didn't go through a complete melt down is the reason I stated before the reaction is unsustainable. The containment breach at Chernobyl was caused by the explosion from when the control rods melted and exposed the sodium inside to the coolant water. The insueing shock wave from the explosion caused the partial colapse of the containment building.
